Award.AwardTitle: Studies on Agrocin 84-a "Trojan Horse" tRNA synthetase inhibitor

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. A vast number of microbial secondary metabolites have been shown to have antimicrobial properties. The biological functions of these molecules can be complex and reflect the highly complex relationships in which microbes engage. This project focuses on agrocin 84, a bacteriocin, produced by the soil bacterium Agrobacterium radiobacter strain K84. Agrocin 84 targets the plant pathogenic bacterium Agrobacterium tumefaciens, which induces tumors in the plant. Agrocin 84 acts a molecular ?Trojan Horse? by mimicking a plant tumor-derived substrate, and thus gaining access to the interior of the cell, where it is processed into a toxin, TM84. TM84 is a potent inhibitor of leucyl-tRNA synthetase, (LeuRS), an essential enzyme that catalyzes the condensation of a leucine to its cognate tRNA and is responsible for the correct translation of the genetic code. Interestingly, the bacterial source of the toxin, Agrobacterium radiobacter, survives by having an alternative synthetase, AgnB2, that is resistant to TM84. The aims of this project are: to determine how TM84 inhibits LeuRS and to determine the basis for AgnB2 resistance to TM84. The research has the to reveal novel insights into the protein translation machinery and to expand understanding of how microbes interact.

Broader Impacts. The project has a major educational goal of increasing underrepresented minority participation in the field of biochemistry. This will be achieved by early exposure of high school and undergraduate students to the science of biochemistry, research experience in the laboratory, and mentorship through programs incorporating lectures, seminars and hands-on research experience in the field of biochemistry. Graduate student training and mentoring will be integrated throughout the research and education plans to enhance professional and scientific development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  The bacterium Agrobacterium radiobacter strain K84 is used world-wide to protect economically important crops such as walnuts, almonds, apples and stone fruits from the tumor-producing bacterium, Agrobacterium tumefaciens, which is the causative agent of crown gall disease. A. radiobacter strain K84 acts as a biocontrol against crown gall by producing a molecule, agrocin 84, that is not needed for its own growth or reproduction, but it acts as an effective antibiotic against the plant pathogen A. tumefaciens. At the onset of our work, it was known that agrocin 84 resembles a beneficial molecule to the A. tumefaciens bacterium, gaining access to the interior of the bacterium, where it is converted into a toxic molecule, TM84. This conversion to a toxin, after accessing the interior of the pathogen, suggests agrocin 84 is acting as a molecular Trojan Horse. The toxicity of TM84 is a direct result of it inhibiting the production of any new bacterial proteins, thereby stopping the A. tumefaciens growth and reproduction. The target of TM84 is a molecule called leucyl-tRNA synthetase (LeuRS). LeuRS catalyzes the critical step of attachment of one of the building blocks of proteins, the amino acid leucine, to a particular transfer RNA (tRNA) involved in translating genes into proteins. TM84 binds to the LeuRS in the A. tumefaciens bacterium, stopping it from functioning properly. Interestingly, A. radiobacter strain K84 resists self-poisoning and is unharmed by the toxin it produces because it has evolved a LeuRS called AgnB2 that is resistant to the antibiotic TM84. Our work has successfully answered two questions about this antibiotic TM84. 1) How does TM84 inhibit the LeuRS from the pathogenic A. tumefaciens? 2) What makes AgnB2, the LeuRS from A. radiobacter strain K84, resistant to its own TM84 toxin?

 

Project Outcomes.  Our findings revealed that the toxicity of TM84 for the LeuRS from A. tumefaciens is unlike any previously reported inhibitors of LeuRS, employing a unique mechanism requiring binding of tRNA for tight binding of TM84. We characterized the tRNA-dependence of inhibition of the LeuRS using thermodynamic and kinetic analyses. In addition, we utilized fluorescent studies to identify conformational changes in the CCA 3'-end of the tRNA upon TM84 binding. Lastly, we detailed the interactions between molecules in the LeuRS/tRNA/TM84 complex using crystallographic studies. Our findings further revealed that resistance to TM84 in AgnB2 resulted from elimination of the tRNA-dependence of TM84 binding. Kinetic studies revealed that tRNA had a reduced effect on the affinity of TM84 for AgnB2, in contrast to the LeuRS from A. tumefaciens. Further insights were gained by crystallographic studies of AgnB2 bound to the Leu-AMS inhibitor formed in the AgnB2/tRNA/Leu-AMS ternary complex. Structural comparisons pointed to key amino acids that when mutated a) converted the TM84-inhibited LeuRS from A. tumefaciens into an enzyme resistant to TM84, as well as b) converted the TM84-resistant AgnB2 into an enzyme inhibited by TM84.

 

The complexity of the molecular mechanisms driving the antibiotic nature of the TM84 toxin were much more complex than one would expect a priori, involving residues on the periphery of the active site and potentially involving dynamic behavior of the LeuRS molecule. As such, this novel mechanism of a tRNA-dependent antibiotic has the potential for applications in the development of novel anti-infectives as well as the enhancement of biocontrol.

 

Broader Impact:  In tandem with completing our research goals, we actively worked to interest middle and high school students in careers in STEM fields, as well as give them a first-hand view into the discipline we call research. As scientists, we described our research to middle school students in their classrooms, taught science modules to high school students during the annual career day called the North Carolina DNA Day, and participated in summer courses for under-represented minority undergraduates sponsored by the Biophysical Society. During completion of our research goals, we trained one undergraduate as a research technician in a laboratory, and a second undergraduate in structural bioinformatic computational tools as he received training for a post-military professional career. We also trained a postdoctoral student for an independent career in research suitable for either an academic or a non-academic environment.
